Convexity

Convex set

A set S⊆Rn is convex if

x1​,x2​∈S,λ∈(0,1)⟹λx1​+(1−λ)x2​∈S

Affine hull

The affine hull of a finite set V={v1,v2,…,vk} is defined as

affV:={λ1​v1+⋯+λk​vk∣∣∣∣∣​λ1​,…,λk​∈R,i=1∑k​λi​=1}

The convex hull of a finite set V={v1,v2,…,vk} is defined as

convV:={λ1​v1+⋯+λk​vk∣∣∣∣∣​λ1​,…,λk​≥0,i=1∑k​λi​=1}

Affine combination

An affine combination of the points {v1​,…,vn​} is a vector satisfying

v=i=1∑n​λi​vi​

where ∑i=1n​λi​=1

Convex combination

A convex combination of the points {v1​,…,vn​} is a vector satisfying

v=i=1∑n​λi​vi​

where ∑i=1n​λi​=1 and λi​≥0 for every i=1,…,n

Polytype

A set P⊂Rn is a polytype if it is the convex hull of finitely many points in Rn.

Polyhedron

A set P⊂Rn is a polyhedron if there exists a matrix A∈Rm×n and a vector b∈Rm such that

P={x∈Rn∣Ax≤b}

The set P is the intersection of m half-spaces. Polyhedrons may be unbounded.

Cone

A set C⊆Rn is a cone if λx∈C whenever x∈C and λ>0.

Polyhedral cone

The set {x∈Rn∣Ax≤0m} where A∈Rm×n is a cone but also a polyhedron, which is why it is usually called a polyhedral cone.

Half space

A half space is the set the cuts the space in two parts

{x∈Rn∣ai​x≤bi​}

Convex function

Suppose that S⊆Rn is a convex set, then a function f:Rn→R is convex on S if

x1,x2∈S,λ∈(0,1)⟹f(λx1+(1−λ)x2)≤λf(x1)+(1−λ)f(x2)
  • A function is strictly convex if the inequality is strict.
  • A function f is concave if −f is convex.

Note that linear functions are both convex and concave.

Carathéodory's Theorem

Let x∈convV where V⊆Rn. Then x can be expressed as a convex combination of n+1 or fewer points of V.

Representation Theorem

The Representation Theorem states that every polyhedron that has at least one extreme point is the sum of a polytope and a polyhedral cone.

Farkas' Lemma

Let A∈Rm×n and b∈Rm. Then exactly one of the systems has a feasible solution

Axx​=b≥0​

and

ATybTy​≤0>0​

and the other one is inconsistent.

Existence of optimal solutions

Notation

  • We say that a set S⊆Rn is open if for every x∈S there exists an ϵ>0 such that Bϵ​(x):={y∈Rn∣∥y−x∥<ϵ}⊂S.
  • A set S⊆Rn is closed if Rn\S is open.
  • A limit point of a set S⊆Rn is a point x such that there exists a sequence {xk​}k=1∞​⊂S fulfilling xk​→x.
  • We can then define a closed set as a set which contains all its limit points.
  • We say that a set S⊆Rn is bounded if there exists a constant C>0 such that ∥x∥≤C for all x∈S.
  • If a set is both closed and bounded, we call it compact.

Definition

Weakly coercive function

A function f is said to be weakly coercive with respect to the set S if either S is bounded or

∥x∥→∞x∈S​lim​f(x)=∞

Lower semi-continuity

A function f is said to be lower semi-continuous at x if the value f(x) is less than or equal to every limit of f as xk​→x

xk​→x⟹f(x)≤k→∞lim inf​f(xk​)

Feasible direction

Let x∈S. A vector p∈Rn defines a feasible direction at x if

∃δ>0:x+αp∈S,∀α∈[0,δ].

The feasible direction is therefore a direction at a point where we can move without becoming infeasible.

Descent direction

Let x∈Rn. A vector p∈Rn defines a descent direction with respect to f at x if

∃δ>0:f(x+αp)<f(x),∀α∈(0,δ].

Normal cone

Suppose the set S is closed and convex. Let x∈S. Then the normal cone to S at x is the set

Ns​(x):={p∈Rn∣pT(y−x)≤0,y∈S}

Weierstrass' Theorem

Consider the problem where S is a nonempty and closed set and f is lower semi-continuous on S. If f is weakly coercive with respect to S, then there exists a nonempty, closed and bounded (compact) set of optimal solutions to the problem.

Linear programming (LP)

For linear problems of the sort

mins.t.​cTxx∈P​

we can use the Simplex method to solve for an optimal solution. We first convert to standard form:

mins.t.​cTxAx=bx≥0​

where b≥0.

Basic solution

A point x is a basic solution if Ax=b and the columns of A corresponding to non-zero elements of x are linearly independent.

Basic feasible solution (BFS)

A point x is a BFS if x≥0, Ax=b and the columns of A corresponding to non-zero elements in x are linearly independent.

Degenerate BFS

Consider a BFS with x=[xB​xN​]T. By definition xN​=0 and xB​=B−1b. If some elements of xB​ are zero the BFS is called degenerate.

Simplex method

Consider

mins.t.​cTxx∈P​

Convert this problem to standard form. To find an initial BFS solve the Phase I problem. That is add as many artificial variables as you need to form the initial base vector as the identity matrix and consider minimizing the artificial variables. Use the Simplex method to move out all artificial variables from the base vector. When this is achieved we have solved the Phase I problem. If we can form the identity matrix without artificial variables go directly to the Phase II problem with this as the base. When we have an initial BFS we solve the Phase II problem, that is the original problem. For each iteration begin by determining xB​=B−1b and xN​=0, e.g. we could have xB​=[x1​x2​]T and xN​=[s1​s2​]T. We also calculate B and N which corresponds to the same variables for the partition in A, as well as cB​ and cN​ in a similar manner. Then we calculate the incoming variable (from N) with the following formula:

c~NT​=cNT​−cBT​B−1N

Then we need to calculate the outgoing variable (from B). We do this by

k:(B−1Nj​)k​>0arg min​=(B−1Nj​)k​(B−1b)k​​

We update the variables and go back and start over. We need to check that B−1b≥0 for feasible solution, that B−1Nj​≥0 so that we do not have an unbounded solution. We terminate the algorithm when our cost vector cNT​≥0.

Perturbation

A perturbation is a small change to either A,c or b.

Subgradient method

For convex problems we can relax the differentiability assumption and use something like the subgradient method. Let S⊆Rn be a nonempty convex set and let f:S→R be a convex function. The p∈Rn is called a subgradient of f at xˉ∈S if

f(x)≥f(xˉ)+pT(x−xˉ),for any x∈S.

The set of all subgradients to f at xˉ is called the subdifferential of f and is defined as

∂f(xˉ)={p∈Rn∣f(x)≥f(xˉ)+pT(x−xˉ),for all x∈S}

Feasible direction methods

These methods are just as local as unconstrained methods, but we find search direction in different ways and termination criteria is often based on KKT. For general sets it could be tricky to find search directions and step lengths. Three well known methods are the Frank-Wolfe method, Simplicial decomposition and the Gradient projection algorithm. These method apply on polyhedron.

Frank-Wolfe method

The idea of the Frank-Wolfe method is to calculate the direction of a linear approximation at a point x, find the nearest extreme point with the simplex method and go in the direction of the extreme point.

Simplicial decomposition

It works like the Frank-Wolfe algorithm but it remembers previous extreme points and searches in the convex hull of these points for the next iterations.

Gradient projection algorithm

Based on the idea that this holds at a local min:

x∗=ProjX​[x∗−∇f(x∗)]

For every iteration choose the next xk+1​ as follows

xk+1​=ProjX​[xk​−αk​f(xk​)]

where αk​>0 for some feasible direction.
